etymologies: Middle English: reduced form of Old English alswā ‘similarly’ (see also)

notes.text: A small, seemingly innocent word, as is so frequently misused (or not used where needed) that interested writers are advised to consult a full-length usage guide for counsel on its proper use. As is often used in causal senses in place of because or since (As Julie wasn't hungry, she ordered only a cup of coffee); in such constructions, where as may cause confusion, it is generally advisable to use the unambiguous because, or since. On whether it is more correct to say he's not as shy as I rather than he's not as shy as me, or I live in the same street as she rather than I live in the same street as her, see personal pronoun. On whether it is more correct to say he's not as shy as I rather than he's not as shy as me, or I live in the same street as she rather than I live in the same street as her, see personal pronoun. For a discussion of when to use as rather than like, see like

definitions: used in comparisons to refer to the extent or degree of something

examples.text: go as fast as you can
it tasted like grape juice but not as sweet
hailstones as big as tennis balls
as many as twenty-two rare species may be at risk

notes.text: A small, seemingly innocent word, as is so frequently misused (or not used where needed) that interested writers are advised to consult a full-length usage guide for counsel on its proper use. As is often used in causal senses in place of because or since (As Julie wasn't hungry, she ordered only a cup of coffee); in such constructions, where as may cause confusion, it is generally advisable to use the unambiguous because, or since. On whether it is more correct to say he's not as shy as I rather than he's not as shy as me, or I live in the same street as she rather than I live in the same street as her, see personal pronoun. On whether it is more correct to say he's not as shy as I rather than he's not as shy as me, or I live in the same street as she rather than I live in the same street as her, see personal pronoun. For a discussion of when to use as rather than like, see like

definitions: used to indicate that something happens during the time when something is taking place

examples.text: Frank watched him as he ambled through the crowd
as she grew older, she kept more to herself

definitions: used to indicate by comparison the way that something happens or is done

examples.text: they can do as they wish
she kissed him goodbye, as usual
dress as you would if you were having guests
as in the past, a collection is to be taken

definitions: used to add or interject a comment relating to the statement of a fact

examples.text: as you can see, I didn't go after all
he has, as you know, called for a referendum
I must stop now as I have to go out

synonyms.text: on account of the fact that
in view of the fact that

examples.text: sweet as he is, he doesn't pay his bills
try as he might, he failed to pull it off

synonyms.text: in spite of the fact that

As is often used in causal senses in place of because or since (As Julie wasn't hungry, she ordered only a cup of coffee); in such constructions, where as may cause confusion, it is generally advisable to use the unambiguous because, or since. For a discussion of when to use as rather than like, see like

definitions: used to refer to the function or character that someone or something has

examples.text: it came as a shock
he got a job as a cook
they were treated as foreigners
as a dairy producer, you should evaluate and analyze your farm from many viewpoints

synonyms.text: so as to appear to be

definitions: during the time of being (the thing specified)

examples.text: he had often been sick as a child
as a student, my nickname was Space
